messages.messageBody:
List-

Can Peter Bleed contact me at this email address.
There seems to be some sort of problem with his email.

Email messages to him have bounced, and an attempt to
reply to a message of his from the above '.edu'
address seems to have bounced as well.

Curran
neobliviscar@...

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] missing national treasures
messages.msgSnippet: Peter, Interesting.  In the intro to the missing kokuho section list in the YNL, Yamanaka mentions contributing to a magazine article on the subject by Alan
messages.messageBody:
Peter,
Interesting. In the intro to the missing kokuho section list in the YNL,
Yamanaka mentions contributing to a magazine article on the subject by Alan
Schwartz. He doesn't mention the name of the magazine the article was
published in... for reasons that are now obvious assuming that this is the
same article. The date would be a rough match.

Jim



Jim and All,
I got the magazine out last night and think it is interesting enough in the
history of sword collecting to recall to other. The article appears in the
SAGA, 1965, I think the August issue. The 'article' is really very short
and full of total hooey. Yamanaka is mentioned as the authority but not the
author. There are about a dozen nicely mounted swords shown
non-technically. These are noted as from the Ussui collection, but not
described at all. Then there is the list of 14 lost treasures. Each of
these gets a couple of paragraphs that list maker, date of recognition, and
date/place of surrender and in most cases the name of the American soldier
who received it. The source of this information is not explained.
My recollection is that the list that Albert presented in the Newsletter
was longer, but much less detailed in that it did not contain all the other
background information. I have never seen this list presented anywhere
else.
Peter

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] missing national treasures
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Peter, but since he is in the 3rd grade, I rather doubt that this would be appropriate. Gordon ... From: Peter A Bleed [mailto:pbleed1@unlnotes.unl.edu]
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Peter, but since he is in the 3rd grade, I rather doubt that this
would be appropriate.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Peter A Bleed [mailto:pbleed1@...]
Sent: Tuesday, October 28, 2003 11:07 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] missing national treasures




Gordon,
Jim has given you the best lists to pass on, but if you wish to point Mom
and kid in the direction of a bit of romance, you should give them the
reference to the 1965+/- men's magazine that had a very lurid article
supposedly by Albert Yamanaka with swords from Bumpei Usui's collection.
That piece as a list of lost treasures together with information on when
and here they were turned in and went missing. It includes kana spelling of
the names of various GI's who supposed accepted the swords. It is much more
fun than a simple list -- but probably less accurate. The kid would also
probably like look at the dirty pictures in the mag and by today's
standard, Mom probably wouldn't mind. I have a copy, but I can't remember
the name.
Peter

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] missing national treasures
messages.msgSnippet: Peter, Interesting.  In the intro to the missing kokuho section list in the YNL, Yamanaka mentions contributing to a magazine article on the subject by Alan
messages.messageBody:
Peter,
Interesting. In the intro to the missing kokuho section list in the YNL, Yamanaka mentions contributing to a magazine article on the subject by Alan Schwartz. He doesn't mention the name of the magazine the article was published in... for reasons that are now obvious assuming that this is the same article. The date would be a rough match.

Jim




Gordon,
Jim has given you the best lists to pass on, but if you wish to point Mom
and kid in the direction of a bit of romance, you should give them the
reference to the 1965+/- men's magazine that had a very lurid article
supposedly by Albert Yamanaka with swords from Bumpei Usui's collection.
That piece as a list of lost treasures together with information on when
and here they were turned in and went missing. It includes kana spelling of
the names of various GI's who supposed accepted the swords. It is much more
fun than a simple list -- but probably less accurate. The kid would also
probably like look at the dirty pictures in the mag and by today's
standard, Mom probably wouldn't mind. I have a copy, but I can't remember
the name.
Peter




[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] missing national treasures
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Jim, I will pass this along too. Gordon ... From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@EARTHLINK.NET] Sent: Tuesday, October 28, 2003 2:36 PM To:
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Jim, I will pass this along too.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Tuesday, October 28, 2003 2:36 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] missing national treasures



If it's just a list, here's the one in Yamanaka's index:

Honjo Masamune
Kuniyuki
Masatsune
Phoenix Tachi
Phoenix Tachi
Rai Kunimitsu
Kunihiro (?) a Kamakura Jyunin [Yamanaka's "(?)," not mine]
Bishu Osafune Iesuke
Nagamitsu
Botan Zukuri Tanto
Archaic Tachi
Norishige Katana
Soshu ju Akihiro
Shumen o Suke Ichinohira Yasuyo

There are no doubt far better qualified people than me to comment on this
list.

Jim



No idea. I don't think she has much of an idea either. She just read
something with her son (elementary school student) and threw out a bunch
of
random questions. As I didn't have a list, I thought most anything would
do.
I will check Jim's site, thanks.



Gordon

Gordon,
Assuming that you're just talking about swords, Albert Yamanaka published
a
list with descriptions in his newsletters, although I have no idea if it
is
complete or correct. He has 14 Kokuho and 25 Juyo Bijutsuhin described.
This was a particular area of interest of the late Jim Kurrasch and he
published something on his web site at
http://members.cox.net/jkk/misimpor.htm Not all of the items that
Yamanaka
mentioned are on Jim's site.

What exactly is she looking for?

Jim
-----

Matt

Rich

gang,

Has anyone ever come across tsuba with shunga theme ?

-M
